title: Physiological processes and lipidome dynamics in the soft coral Sinularia heterospiculata under experimental bleaching
abstract: Coral polyps host intracellular symbiotic dinoflagellates (SD). The loss of SD (referred as bleaching) under stressful environmental conditions is the main reason of coral reef destruction, and therefore, intensively studied over the world. Lipids are the structural base of biomembranes and energy reserve of corals and are directly involved in the coral bleaching. In order to establish a relationship between coral tissue morphology, physiological processes and lipidome dynamics during bleaching, the soft coral Sinularia heterospiculata was exposed to experimental heat stress (33 • C) for 72 h. A chlorophyll content, structure of cells, the level of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and molecular species of storage and structural lipids were analyzed. After 24 h of heat exposure, the level of ROS-positive SD cells did not increase, but the host tissues lost a significant part of SD. The removal of SD cells by exocytosis were suggested. Exocytosis was presumed to prevail at earlier stages of the soft coral bleaching. Symbiophagosomes with degenerative SD were observed in the stressed coral host cells. After 24 h, the content of phosphatidylinositols, which involved in apoptosis and autophagy, was significantly decreased. The innate immune response was triggered, and SD were digested by the coral host. After 48 h, a degradation of SD chloroplasts and a decrease in the specific monogalactosyldiacylglycerol molecular species were detected that confirmed a disruption of lipid biosynthesis in chloroplasts. At the end of coral bleaching, the appearance of oxidized phosphatidylethanolamines, indicating damage to the host membranes, and the degradation of the coral tissues were simultaneously observed. Thus, a switch between dominant mechanisms of the SD loss during bleaching of S. heterospiculata was found and proved by certain variations of the lipidomic profile. Lipidomic parameters may become indicators of physiological processes occurring in the symbiotic coral organism and may be used for assessing anthropogenic or natural destructive effects on coral reefs.

body_text.text: Coral reefs are the home to many species of marine organisms (Spalding and Grenfell, 1997) . Most coral species are symbiotic animals that involve intracellular symbiotic dinoflagellates (SD) or zooxanthellae (Davy et al., 2012) . The existence of symbiotic coral polyps depends on SD that photosynthesize the nutrients essential to the host (Muscatine, 1967) . The loss of SD, and consequent loos in color, occurs when seawater temperature exceed 32 • C. This process is known as coral bleaching (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . Mass coral bleaching is usually associated with global warming (Hughes et al., 2003) .

The process of bleaching begins in SD chloroplasts. Increased temperature and high levels of solar radiation cause photoinhibition and damage to chloroplasts and photosynthetic apparatus of symbiotic cells following by accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which leads to the bleaching cascade (Lesser, 2006; Venn et al., 2008) . ROS can be generated not only in chloroplasts but in mitochondria and peroxisomes of both zooxanthellae and host cells (Weis, 2008) . ROS can trigger second messenger systems (Szabó et al., 2020) . When ROS are accumulated, they diffuse through the plasma membrane of the zooxanthellae and enter the cytoplasm of the host gastrodermis cell (Tchernov et al., 2004; Lesser, 2006) , damaging cell components as lipids (Lesser and Farrell, 2004; Richier et al., 2005; Noctor et al., 2018) , which could be a trigger for the loss of symbionts by exocytosis (Suggett et al., 2008; Gustafsson et al., 2014) . In situ degradation of symbionts and apoptosis or necrosis of symbiosoms was shown to be another mechanism for the zooxanthellae loss (Weis, 2008; Szabó et al., 2020) . Bleaching may be considered as a process of detection and elimination of opportunistic pathogenic zooxanthellae by the coral host (Weis, 2008) . The symbionts indicate their presence during photoinhibition by the production of ROS, and the host cells, in turn, triggers an immune response by producing NO, leading to the destruction of zooxanthellae in situ (Fang, 2004; Gruenberg and van der Goot, 2006; Perez and Weis, 2006) . Degradation of zooxanthellae by autophagy at coral bleaching has been previously confirmed by Dunn et al. (2007) . Stress induces maturation of lysosomes and their fusion with symbiosoms that may result in the digestion of symbionts (Chen et al., 2005) . The described mechanisms for the zooxanthellae loss are reliably confirmed, but the predominance of each mechanism over others under certain conditions is not completely clear.

The thylakoid membrane basis of plant cells composed of three glycolipid (GL) classes: monogalactosyldiacylglycerol (MGDG), digalactosyldiacylglycerol (DGDG), and sulfoquinovosyldiacylglycerol (SQDG) (Li-Beisson et al., 2019) . To cope with the increased temperature, SD uses several strategies including alteration of the membrane lipid structure. The increased heat resistance of thermotolerant SD Durusdinium trenchii may be directly related to the higher DGDG/MGDG ratios even in the absence of heat stress, as opposed to thermosensitive SD Cladocopium C3 (Rosset et al., 2019) . The amount of saturated SQDG and the degree of unsaturation of MGDG and DGDG in D. trenchii were higher than those in Cladocopium C1/C3 (Sikorskaya et al., 2021) . The long-term exposure to an increased temperature led to a decrease in the relative amount of C 18 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in lipids of both SD clades, but the visible thermal threshold of changes in lipids was lower in Cladocopium C1 (Kneeland et al., 2013) . A holobiont heat sensitivity also depends on the coral host ( (Dunn et al., 2004; Lesser and Farrell, 2004; Sammarco and Strychar, 2013) . Phospholipids are the structural base of the host cells and some phospholipid classes are essential for the animal physiology. Translocation of phosphatidylserine (PS) within cellular membrane is known to be an indicator of apoptosis (Elmore, 2007) . Some oxidized phospholipids are the markers of pathological processes (Bochkov et al., 2017; Serbulea et al., 2017; O'Donnell et al., 2019) . Rosic et al. (2015) suggested the involvement of phosphatidylinositol (PI) in symbiotic interactions.

Significant physiological changes in the coral organism during bleaching is known to affect its lipid profile (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012; Hillyer et al., 2017; Sikorskaya et al., 2020) . Bleaching decreases the content of storage lipids (Yamashiro et al., 2005; Schoepf et al., 2015) and alternates the fatty acid (FA) composition (Tolosa et al., 2011) of reef-building corals. Heat exposure strongly influences on FA/lipid class compositions and leads to remodeling of lipid molecular species profiles of soft corals (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012; Sikorskaya et al., 2020) . To date, no synchronous studies of physiological changes and remodeling of lipid molecular species were performed on corals during bleaching induced by thermal stress.

The study of various aspects of bleaching has mainly involved reefbuilding coral species (McLachlan et al., 2020) , though soft coral species being an integral part of the coral reef ecosystem. Soft corals should not be neglected, because recognizing the consequences of heat stress on all members of the coral reef ecosystem will help to predict the survival of whole coral reef ecosystem in the future (McLachlan et al., 2020) .

To clarify the interrelation of physiological processes and lipidome changes in bleached corals, the soft coral Sinularia heterospiculata was exposed to 33 • C for 72 h. The experiment simulated natural physiological responses of corals to extreme low tides in lagoons when the temperature rapidly rises to 35 • C and remains constant for a short period (Oliver and Palumbi, 2011) . We examined phenotypic indicators of bleaching (chlorophyll level and zooxanthellae density) and carried out a lipidomic analysis of storage and structural lipids by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry as indicators of the vital activity of symbionts and the host. At the same time, the physiological changes in host and SD were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and flow cytometry to comprehensively understand bleaching process of S. heterospiculata.

The colonies of the tropical symbiotic soft coral Sinularia heterospiculata Verseveldt, 1970 (Alcyoniidae) were vegetatively propagated and grown up to 10 cm height at 27 • C in an aerated specially designed aquarium (400 L seawater tank) with two pumps providing a flow rate of 6000 l per hour each. Сoral colonies were illuminated at a light intensity of 200 μmol photons m − 2 s − 1 with white fluorescent lamps National, FL20SS-N/18 (Panasonic, Japan) at a 12 h light photocycle following 12 h of darkness. A flow-through-seawater system (Peter the Great Gulf) with protein skimmer for seawater filtration were used.

Before starting the experiment, sixteen colonies of S. heterospiculata were kept in the experimental aquarium (400 L) at 27 • C for 2 weeks for adaptation. Four control colonies from the sea-water tank (27 • C) were collected for the analyses by flow cytometry, TEM, and mass spectrometry. Using aquarium heaters and automatic thermostat (±0.4 • C, Platinum heater (Aquael, Poland), the water temperature was increased from 27 to 33 • C over a period of 8.0 ± 0.4 h and then remained constant (33 • C) during 72 h. At the 0-h exposure point, four colonies were taken out from the experimental aquarium (33 • C) for analyses of a chlorophyll content, lipid composition, and physiological state of coral cells. These analyses were repeated after 24, 48, and 72 h of heat exposure with remained coral colonies. The colonies after 48 h exposure was also analyzed by TEM. The colonies of S. heterospiculata were immediately sampled and used for lipid extraction or for analysis by flow cytometry and TEM.

Symbiosomes and host cells were mechanically knocked out of the coral colony by high pressure, using a jet of 5 mM EDTA buffer in 1.2 μm filtered seawater. Heterogenic cell suspensions isolated from corals were divided into two equal parts. One part was centrifuged at 500g for 5 min, resuspended in 90 μL of annexin-binding buffer (calcium-and magnesium-free artificial seawater (CMFSW) containing 2.5 mM CaCl 2 ). Annexin V is a phosphatidylserine-binding protein, and its complex with FITC is used for detection of PS translocation to the outer membrane surface of apoptotic cells (Elmore, 2007) . The PS in intact live cells is restricted to the inner leaflet of the membrane (Arur et al., 2003) . The cells were stained with 10 μL of Annexin V-FITC solution (Invitrogen, USA) (to detect apoptotic cells) and SYTOX™ Red (Invitrogen) at the final concentration of 5 nM (for staining the nuclei of dead cells with damaged membranes), and incubated for 45 min at room temperature (RT) in the dark. The suspension of cells was then diluted with 150 μL of annexin-binding buffer, centrifuged at 500g for 5 min and re-suspended in 250 μL of annexin-binding buffer followed by flow cytometry. The second part of heterogenic cell suspension was centrifuged at 500g for 5 min and re-suspended in 100 μL of CMFSW. 2 ′ ,7 ′ -dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (H 2 DCFDA) (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) (used for the ROS detection) at a final concentration of 10 μM and SYTOX™ Red at the final concentration of 5 nM were added to the cells and incubated at RT for 45 min in the dark. The cell suspension was then diluted with 150 μL of CMFSW, centrifuged at 500g for 5 min, and re-suspended in 250 μL of CMFSW followed by flow cytometry. Flow cytometrical analyses were conducted within 20 min after staining using a CytoFLEX flow cytometer (Beckman-Coulter, Brea, CA, USA) connected to a computer running CytExpert software (version 2.3, Beckman-Coulter). In flow cytometry, an "event" is defined as a single particle (cell fragment, single cell or aggregated cells) detected by the instrument. The sequential exclusion of cell aggregates and debris from an analysis of cytometrical data is required for the obtaining of reliable results. Single events made up more than 90% of total events in each sample and were determined by triangle gating on FSC-A against FSC-H plot in order to exclude cell aggregates from the following analysis. Single events possessing autofluorescence at excitation 488 nm and emission at 690/50 BP were considered as chlorophyll-positive algal cells (zooxanthellae), while other cells were considered as host cells. The proportion of chlorophyllpositive cells is presented as a percentage of the total single events. H 2 DCFDA-positive (both zooxanthellae and host) cells or Annexin V-FITC-positive host cells were detected at 488 nm excitation and 525/40 BP emission. SYTOX™ Red-positive host cells were detected at 638 nm excitation and 660/10 BP emission.

To study the effect of high temperature (33 • С) on the morphology of symbiotic zooxanthellae and the coral host cells, coral samples were taken 48 h after heat exposure. Control samples were taken from corals grown at normal temperature (27 • С). About 5 mm 3 of a coral tissue sample was excised, fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde on 0.05 M cacodylate buffer at pH 7.5 for 24 h at 4 • C. After fixing, the material was washed in buffer and fixed in 1% OsO 4 in cacodylate buffer. Decalcification was carried out for 2 days in a solution of ascorbic acid (Dietrich and Fontaine, 1975) . Samples were dehydrated in ascending concentrations of ethanol and acetone and embedded in Araldite. Sections were cut with glass knives on an ultratome Ultracut UC6 (Leica, Germany). Ultrathin (60-75 nm) sections were collected on copper grids after staining with uranyl acetate and lead citrate and examined using a Carl Zeiss Libra 120 transmission electron microscope or a Carl Zeiss Sigma 300 Vp scanning electron microscope equipped with a STEM-detector. The microscopic studies were performed at the "Far Eastern Center of Electron Microscopy" (National Scientific Center of Marine Biology, Far Eastern Branch of Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok, Russia).

Hexane, benzene, chloroform, methanol, and 28% NH 4 OH of analytical grade were used for lipid extraction and thin-layer chromatography (TLC). Hexane, 2-propanol, formic acid, triethylamine of LC-MS grade (Sigma-Aldrich) were used for HPLC. TLC was performed on ready-to-use Sorbfil HPTLC-A silica gel plates, 10 × 10 cm (Sorbis Group, Russia). GL and phosphorus-containing lipids (PL) standards were purchased from Avanti Polar Lipids Inc. (USA). Tridecylpalmitate (analytical grade) was purchased from KNPO Diagnostikum (Russia).

For analysis of the concentration of chlorophylls (a and b) the fresh coral tissues (about 0.5 g) was homogenized by disperser (IKA T25 digital Ultra-Turrax, Germany) in 10 mL of acetone -water (9:1) mixture and then left for an hour in the dark. The pigment quantification was made by spectrophotometry (chlorophyll a at 663 nm; chlorophyll b at 645 nm) according to Lichtenthaler (1987) . The chlorophyll content was measured in the immediately sampled S. heterospiculata colonies as μg of chlorophyll per gram of wet weight of the colony tissues.

Total lipid extracts were obtained according to Folch et al. (1957) with some modifications. A sample (~5 g) of fresh coral colonies was homogenized by disperser (IKA T25 digital Ultra-Turrax, Germany) in 10 mL of chloroform-methanol (1:2) mixture, filtered, and the residues were extracted twice with 10 mL of chloroform-methanol (2:1) mixture. The extracts were combined, mixed with chloroform (10 mL) and water (15 mL) and then left overnight for phase separation at 4 • С. Then, the bottom layer was separated and evaporated; total lipids were dissolved in a small volume of chloroform under argon and stored at − 40 • С. Proportion of the lipid extract per dry weight of sample was determined gravimetrically.
Amounts of PL were measured on a UV-1800 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan) based on the amount of inorganic phosphorus upon oxidation in HClO 4 according to Vaskovsky et al. (1975) .

Total lipids were separated by TLC in a chloroform:methanol:(2%) NH 4 OH:benzene (65:30:5:10) mixture and the amounts of GL were quantified by densitometry of TLC plates (Hamoutene et al., 2008; Imbs et al., 2015) . Contents and structures of PL and GL molecular species were analyzed by a HPLC system with a high-resolution tandem mass spectrometer with electrospray ionization at positive and negative modes (Imbs et al., 2015) . The total lipids were separated on a Shim-Pack diol column (4.6 mm × 50 mm, particle size 5 μm) (Shimadzu, Japan) using a Nexera-e chromatography system (Shimadzu, Japan). Solvent system A (2-propanol:hexane:H 2 O:HCOOH:(28%)NH 4 OH:Et 3 N, 28:72:1.5:0.1:0.05:0.02, by volume) and solvent system B (2-propanol: H 2 O:HCOOH:(28%)NH 4 OH:Et 3 N, 100:1.5:0.1:0.05:0.02, by volume) were used as eluents. The percentage of system B in the total solvent flow was programmed as follows: 0 to 20% (7 min), 20 to 100% (5 min), 100% (5 min), 100 to 0% (0.1 min), and 0% (10 min). Elution rate was 0.2 mL min − 1 . To detect lipids, a high-resolution tandem mass spectrometer LCMS-IT-TOF (Shimadzu, Japan) was used. Analysis was performed under electrospray ionization (ESI) mode with simultaneous registration of signals of positive and negative ions. Scanning was performed in a m/z range of 100-1200. Source voltage was − 3.5 kV in case of negative ion formation and 4.5 kV in case of formation of positive ions. The temperature of the ion source was 250 • С; dry gas (N 2 ) pressure, 200 kPa; the flow rate of nebulizing gas (N 2 ), 1.5 L min − 1 . Argon (0.003 Pa) was used in the collision chamber of the mass spectrometer.

Percentages of the individual molecular species of each lipid class were calculated by peak area of negative ions [M-H] − , except for phosphatidylcholine (PC)/ lyso-phosphatidylcholine (LPC) and MGDG/DGDG, which was determined by peak area of positive ions [M + H] + and [M + Na] + , respectively. Identification of molecular species was performed as described earlier (Imbs et al., 2015; Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018; Imbs et al., 2019) . Amounts of triacylglycerols (TG) and monoalkyldiacylglycerols (MADAG) in total lipids were measured by densitometry of images of the analytical TLC plates according to (Hamoutene et al., 2008; Imbs et al., 2015) , using the Sorbfil Videodensitometer software (Russia). The internal wax ester (WE) standard (13:0/16:0, 480 μg mL − 1 ) was added to aliquots of the total lipids. WE were isolated by preparative TLC of the total lipids in the hexane:benzene (70:30) system, dissolved in chloroform, and stored at − 18 • С. Quantitative analysis of the molecular species of WE was performed on a gas chromatograph GC-2010 (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with flame ionization detector and an Equity-5 (0.25 mm × 30 m, film thickness 0.25 μm) quartz capillary column (Supelco, USA).

The raw data on chlorophylls and lipid contents were used following examination of the homogeneity of variances (Levene's test) and the normality of the data (Shapiro-Wilk's test). Significant differences between levels within the factors were examined post hoc with Tukey-Kramer HSD test. All statistical analyses were performed using STATISTICA 6 (StatSoft, USA). A statistical probability of p < 0.05 was considered significant. Values are reported as the mean ± standard deviation.

Flow cytometrical data were obtained from four biological samples. At least 50,000 single events were analyzed by flow cytometry for each sample. Comparison of the percentage of live, dead, apoptotic and ROSpositive cells between control and experimental cells were performed by using Z-test in MS Office Excel 2013 software (Microsoft Corporation, USA). A statistical probability of p < 0.05 was considered significant.
Microscopic organization of the tentacle tissue of the soft coral S. heterospiculata grown at normal temperature (27 • С) are described in detail in supplementary material.
body_text.section: Ultrastructural changes in SD and host cells after 48 h of heat exposure (33 • С)

body_text.text: The epidermal structure of the tentacles broke down after the heat stress ( Fig. 1 A, B) . The epidermis consisted of disordered clusters of granular amebocytes and myoepithelial cells with the signs of differentiation lost (Fig. 1D ). Myoepithelial cells lost contact with each other and the basal lamina, were round, lost microvilli and the myofibril-containing part of the cytoplasm in the form of structures with disintegrated myofibrils (Fig. 1F, G) . Most epithelial cells had signs of degradation. Their cytoplasm contained the remains of secretory granules, autophagosomes and residual bodies. Necrotic-like epidermal cells were detected in phagosomal vacuoles and cytoplasm of granular amoebocytes (Fig. 1J) . The amoebocytes had a winding plasma membrane and contained myelin-like bodies (Fig. 1H) . A decrease in the number of SD was noticed in gastrodermis (Fig. 1B) . Some of them were removed by exocytosis into the external environment. Almost all remaining zooxanthellae had signs of apoptosis ( Fig. 2C ; 3B, C). SD were not tightly attached to the host membrane; an increase in the volume of the vacuolar matrix in the symbiosome was observed. The most significant structural degradation was detected in chloroplasts: they lost a clear elongated shape at early and mid apoptosis (Fig. 3B ). Chloroplast sites merged to form larger and rounded organelle bodies. The structure of thylakoids was disturbed. Clusters of pigmentprotein complexes appeared in the stromal gaps between thylakoid grana (Fig. 3F ). Thylakoids were partially destroyed or lost their parallel arrangement and close contacts with each other in grana (Fig. 3G) . Disintegrated thylakoid membranes and pigment-protein clusters randomly filled the chloroplast stroma. The disappearance of clear parallel gaps between the grana in the stroma was observed. At the same time, the fragmentation of chloroplasts occurred (Fig. 3H) . Compact fragments were enveloped by an adjacent chloroplast membrane, condensed, and formed electron-dense rounded apoptotic bodies. The number of apoptotic bodies increased at the late apoptosis (Fig. 3C) . Chloroplast lamellae were sometimes detected as "free-floating" cells in the cytoplasm (Fig. 3N ). Apoptotic bodies, smaller than that at chloroplast destruction, were formed after mitochondria fragmentation (Fig. 3H ). Chromatin structure changes occurred in the nuclei. Many cells had despiralized chromosomes and condensed (or, at the late apoptosis, fragmented) interchromosomal chromatin (Fig. 3J, K) . The nuclear membrane of some cells was damaged. The number of electrondense spots of different diameter increased in the accumulation body (Fig. 3N) . Lipid droplets were rare and had a loose heterogeneous structure (Fig. 3O ). Plastoglobules were slightly larger and denser than the normal ones (Fig. 3P) . The number of glyoxysomes was visually increased compared with the control animal tissues.
body_text.section: Ultrastructural changes in SD and host cells after 48 h of heat exposure (33 • С)

body_text.text: Most host cells in the gastrodermis was shown to have vacuolated cytoplasm after exposure to increased temperature (Fig. 2F) . The cytoplasm contained large vacuoles, a well-developed Golgi apparatus, multivesicular bodies, phagosomes and residual bodies (Fig. 2D, H) . Some cells contained symbiophagosomes with degrading SD (Fig. 2F ). Necrotic SD found in the cytoplasm of the host cells had a winding cell wall (Fig. 3K ). Many residual bodies were fragments of degraded chloroplasts (Fig. 3D, K) . The areas with parallel thylakoid membranes were observed in some chloroplasts (Fig. 3L) .
body_text.section: Ultrastructural changes in SD and host cells after 48 h of heat exposure (33 • С)

body_text.text: The functional activity of the host cells before and after the heat exposure is presented in Fig. 4A and Supplementary Fig. S1 . The proportion of live host cells reached 80% in control samples of coral and reliably decreased to 66% only after 72 h of exposure to high temperature. Apoptotic cells made up 18% of control host cells and showed a significant decrease to 7.7% only after 48 h of the experiment. Not more than 5% of control cells were dead. The proportion of dead cells gradually increased each day of the exposure and reached 16% after 72 h. A decrease of chlorophyll-positive cells (symbiotic dinoflagellates) has been observed immediately after increasing the temperature to 33 • С ( Fig. 4B and Supplementary Fig. S1 ). The proportion of SD decreased from 31% (in control) to 8.6% (after 24 h exposure) and remained at this level. The heat exposure resulted in the increase of ROS-positive SD from 30% in control to 63% after 72 h.

The lipidomes of control colonies and experimental colonies after 0, 24, 48, and 72-h exposure to the increased temperature were determined (Supplementary Table S1 ). The lipid data on the control colonies are not shown in figures, because no significant differences in all lipid values were found between the control and 0-h point colonies (HSD test, p > 0.05) (Table S1 ).

After 24 h exposure at 33 • C, the amount of chlorophyll a in coral tissues ( Fig. 5A; Supplementary Table S1 ) and the content of glycolipids DGDG+SQDG in the coral lipid extract decreased two-fold (HSD test, p < 0.05) ( Fig. 5D ; Supplementary Table S1 ). During the experiment, the content of chlorophyll b has not changed (HSD test, p > 0.05) ( Fig. 5A ; Supplementary Table S1 ).

At the beginning of the experiment (0 h), the most abundant GL molecular species were MGDG 16:3/20:5, 18:4/18:4, 18:4/18:5, 16:4/ 20:5, 16:3/18:4 (66.9 ± 11.0% of total MGDG), DGDG 18:4/20:5, 16:3/ 22:6, 18:4/18:4, 16:3/20:5 (49.6 ± 6.9% of total DGDG), and SQDG 14:0/16:0, 14:1/16:0, 16:0/16:0 (86.4 ± 0.5% of total SQDG) (Supplementary Table S2 ). Total MGDG were composed of the molecular species with C 16 PUFA and other molecular species, which had no C 16 PUFA but contained C 18-22 PUFA. After 48-h exposure, the profile of molecular species of MGDG changed, and the percentage of MGDG with C 16 PUFA significantly decreased (HSD test, p < 0.05) from 44.1 ± 4.5 to 30.9 ± 2.1% of total MGDG (Fig. 5B) . The profile of molecular species of DGDG has not changed (HSD test, p > 0.05) during the experiment.

Total, storage, and structural lipids of the host cells of S. heterospiculata have significantly varied during the experiment. After 48 h of exposure, the content of the total lipids in coral tissue markedly decreased (HSD test, p < 0.05) from 6.9 to 1.5% ( Fig. 5C ; Supplementary  Table S1 ). The percentage of TG + MADAG in the total lipids significantly increased (HSD test, p < 0.05) after 48-h exposure and then, halved after 72 h (HSD test, p < 0.05) (Fig. 5D ). The percentage of WE in the total lipids noticeably increased (HSD test, p < 0.05) after 48 h of exposure, but decreased (HSD test, p < 0.05) at the end of the experiment ( Fig. 5D ; Supplementary Table S1 ). After 48 h, the content of PL in the total lipids decreased twice (HSD test, p < 0.05) ( Fig. 5D) .

At the beginning of the experiment, six major polar lipid classes (choline-, ethanolamine-, inositol-, and serineglycerophospholipids (PC, PE, PI, and PS, respectively), ceramide aminoethylphosphonate (CAEP), and lyso-form of cholineglycerophospholipids (LPC) were detected in PL of S. heterospiculata (Fig. 5E ). According to TLC analysis, after 48 h of exposure to 33 • C, lyso-form of PE (LPE) appeared, but CAEP and LPE partly overlapped on a TLC plate and were therefore quantified in total (Supplementary Table S1 ).

The significant reduction (HSD test, p < 0.05) of the levels of PC and PE but the rising of the level of CAEP+LPE were observed at the end of the experiment (Fig. 5E ). Two new molecular species of oxidized derivative of PE (oxPE) were detected in traces after 48-h exposure but made up 16.6 ± 5.6% of total PL after 72 h ( Fig. 5E ; Supplementary  Table S2 , Fig. S2 ). A significant reduction (HSD test, p < 0.05) in the level of PI was found, and this class was not detected in the total lipids at the end of our experiment (Fig. 5E) .

The temperature and time factors did not affect PS and LPC (Fig. 5E ). Several molecular species of oxidized derivatives of PS (oxPS) were detected. The content of oxPS molecular species in the total lipids has not changed after 48 h, but significantly increased (HSD test, p < 0.01) from 3.5 ± 0.8 to 5.8 ± 1.2% at the end of the experiment (Supplementary Table S2 ).

The experimental bleaching at increased temperature has shown significant physiological and biochemical changes in the host and symbionts of the coral S. heterospiculata, which lead to fatal consequences for the organism. To characterize the coral responses to heat stress and to compare our results with other experimental coral bleaching studies, we followed the protocol applied by McLachlan et al. (2020) . We described the bleaching process within the three main categories: bleaching phenotype, symbiont phenotype and holobiont phenotype.

Bleaching phenotype is a way to record the degree of paleness or photosynthetic function of corals in a heat stress experiment (McLachlan et al., 2020) . On this way, the dynamics of symbiotic cell proportion and photosynthetic pigments (chlorophylls) content were determined in our study. A three-fold decrease in the chlorophyll-positive cell proportion of total cells and a halving of the chlorophyll a content in coral tissues indicated a considerable loss of SD and a decrease of photosynthetic function of S. heterospiculata within 24 h after the beginning of temperature increase. Contrary to chlorophyll a, the content of chlorophyll b did not change. Chlorophyll b is the second most abundant chlorophyll in algae. If chlorophyll a is found in the reaction centers and light harvesting antenna complexes (LHC) of photosystem I (PSI) and II (PSII), then chlorophyll b is found in the LHC's and as accessory pigments of PSII (Willows, 2020). Significant changes have been suggested to occur plastoglobuli, respectively. in PSI of SD under heat stress of S. heterospiculata. On the other hand, several studies proposed PSII to be the main damaged site resulting in coral bleaching (Jones et al., 2000; Ragni et al., 2010) . All these studies have shown the decrease in activity of PSII by pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) fluorescence techniques. Such decrease may appear as a secondary effect if electron transport through PSI were impaired. The involvement of PSI in coral bleaching is insufficiently characterized, mainly due to its too high complexity (Szabó et al., 2020) .

The reef-building corals Acropora intermedia, Montipora digitata and the soft coral Sinularia capitalis have been shown to lose a most part of their symbionts after 10, 30, and 24 h at 33 • C, respectively (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012) . A rapid initial loss of SD and photosynthetic pigments was observed in the sea anemone Aiptasia sp. within 18-48 h of heat exposure (Dunn et al., 2004) . The reef-building coral Pocillopora damicornis exposed to 32 • C lost over 60% of their algal symbionts in 48 h (Downs et al., 2013) . Though the dynamics of the bleaching phenotype parameters are species-specific, most cnidarian species lose the main part of SD during first two days of the experimental heat stress.

GL are known to be the structural lipids of thylakoid membranes of plant cells (Li-Beisson et al., 2019) and the lipid markers of coral symbionts (Imbs et al., 2010) . In this work, the content of the main glycolipids in coral colonies after 24 h of exposure decreased in two times and correlated with the SD density and the chlorophyll a content. Hence, the GL level may be used as a bleaching phenotype parameter and an index of coral bleaching degree.

A heat exposure has been shown to induce changes in the isolated SD of three soft coral species similar to reversible early/mid-stage apoptosis and necrosis during 12 h at 32 • C or non-reversible late-stage apoptosis and necrosis during 9 h at 34 • C (Sammarco and Strychar, 2013) . SD expelled from the reef-building coral Stylophora pistillata were found to be dead and photosynthetically non-functional (Franklin et al., 2004) . In our experiment, SD expelled from S. heterospiculata were not controlled, but the signs of early, mid and late apoptosis have been observed in all remaining SD after 48 h of heat exposure. Moreover, necrotic SD were detected in the host gastrodermal cells.

The disturbances in photosynthetic apparatus of SD are known to occur when the ambient temperature increases (Weis, 2008) . GL, as part of the photosynthetic apparatus, are very sensitive to temperature change; for example, the natural circadian rhythm of the GL level was immediately interrupted in the soft coral Sinularia sp. under heat exposure (Sikorskaya et al., 2020) . In the present work, a molecular species profile of the glycolipid MGDG clarified dynamics of the status of SD remaining in the host during bleaching.

According to biosynthetic pathways, MGDG molecules can be divided into "prokaryotic" with C 16 PUFA synthesized in plastids and "eukaryotic" with C 18-20 PUFAs, which are synthesized in endoplasmic reticulum and then transported back into plastids for the synthesis of GL (Li-Beisson et al., 2019) . In S. heterospiculata, the proportion of "prokaryotic" MGDG molecular species did not change after 24 h but remarkably reduced after 48 h of heat exposure. The degradation of symbionts' chloroplasts was also observed. The structure of thylakoids was disturbed, that could reduce a biosynthetic rate and hence, the proportion of "prokaryotic" MGDG molecular species in the SD plastids.

The increase in the number of glyoxysomes was observed in SD after the temperature increase. Glyoxysomes are specialized peroxisomes found in plants (Graham, 2008) . In adverse conditions, SD are known to be susceptible to oxidative stress due to the high production of ROS (Weis, 2008) . Peroxisomes utilize ROS produced in other organelles (Sandalio and Romero-Puertas, 2014) , for example, in the photosynthetic apparatus of zooxanthellae (Weis, 2008) . In S. heterospiculata, 72 h of the high temperature exposure led to the two-fold increase in the percentage of ROS-positive SD cells, possibly, due to the increase of glyoxysome number in them.

Overall, the morphological, physiological, and lipidomic data have shown that the experimental coral colonies rapidly lost their SD during 24 h but saved a group of relatively healthy algal symbionts. Nevertheless, next 24 h of exposure have led to the considerable damages of these remaining SD.

Several mechanisms of SD loss such as exocytosis, apoptosis, phagocytosis, and necrosis were described (Dunn et al., 2007; Davy et al., 2012; Sammarco and Strychar, 2013; Li et al., 2020) . Accumulation of ROS triggers second messenger systems followed by exocytosis and consequent coral bleaching (Szabó et al., 2020) . Active exocytosis was suggested at bleaching of the coral Acropora grandis (Fang et al., 1997) . After 24 h, the considerable rising of ROS was detected in the host tissues of S. heterospiculata. As opposed to the host, remained SD cells showed insignificant increase of ROS level. It is quite possible that SD cells with a high ROS level expelled the host coral cells via exocytosis at the beginning of bleaching.

The signs of apoptosis were observed in all remaining SD after 48 h of heat exposure. Inositolphosphate is known to be involved in processes of apoptosis and autophagy (Boehning et al., 2005; Chakraborty et al., 2008) , as well as, in signal transduction in response to the rise of ROS in reef-building coral at bleaching (Rosic et al., 2015) . Phosphatidylinositol-based signaling pathways was mentioned by Hillyer et al. (2017) as a part of SD response in thermally stressed Acropora aspera (Hillyer et al., 2017) . The rapid decrease of PI proportion that disappeared after 48-h exposure, may be the result of PI involving in apoptosis and autophagy in the soft coral studied.

A relationship between apoptosis and autophagy in corals under heat stress is hypothesized: when one way of cell death is inhibited, the other one is induced (Davy et al., 2012) . A similar relationship between apoptosis and autophagy was observed in vertebrates (Boya et al., 2005) . Dunn et al. (2007) suggested that autophagy can control a symbiont density of the sea anemone Acropora pallida. To maintain tissue homeostasis at coral bleaching, the destruction of damaged cells occurs through apoptosis (Weis, 2008) .

In terrestrial animals, the presence of PS on the outer membrane surface is used as one of the apoptosis markers (Elmore, 2007) . The fluorescent-labeled PS-binding protein annexin V was used in our study to detect apoptotic host cells of S. heterospiculata. Regardless of the time of the high temperature exposure, the level of annexin-positive cells of the coral host was unexpectedly high. This level may be false-positive and resulted from a lower viscosity of plasma membranes and higher mobility of PS between membrane layers in corals than in terrestrial animals (Hochachka and Somero, 2014) . Moreover, as shown by lipidomic analysis, no changes in the content of PS were observed during the experiment.

The formation of symbiosomal cells in cnidarians is regarded as phagocytosis, when innate immunity of the coral host is suspended for an indefinite period (Davy et al., 2012; Mansfield and Gilmore, 2019) . Cnidarians (sea anemones, corals, jellyfish) are very distant systematically from mammals, but they have similar cellular mechanisms associated with the innate immunity. Phagocytic activities have been found in the symbiotic cnidarians (Mansfield and Gilmore, 2019) . Symbiophagosomes with degrading SD were detected in the bleached S. heterospiculata after 48 h of heat exposure, that confirms triggering the innate immune response in S. heterospiculata leading to SD digestion by autophagy described by Davy et al. (2012) .

Necrosis of the coral host cells has been previously observed under strong bleaching conditions (Sammarco and Strychar, 2013) . According to TEM data, the epidermal structure of the tentacles of S. heterospiculata was broken down after 48-h heat exposure. According to flow cytometric and lipidomic analysis, the proportion of necrotic host cells significantly increased, whereas the levels of all lipids critically reduced and the structural lipid profile of the host considerably fluctuated by the end of the experiment. Oxidized phospholipids (oxPE and oxPS) appeared at 48-h point and its content reached 16% of the structural lipids at 72-h point. In our previous experiment, oxPE reached 24% to the end of the experimental bleaching of soft coral Sinularia sp. (Sikorskaya et al., 2020) . Oxidized phospholipids can serve as a signal for immune cells of terrestrial animals (Serbulea et al., 2017) , but the lipid class giving one fifth of the total structural lipids should not be considered as a "signal" molecule class. The considerable number of oxidized phospholipids disrupts the structure of cell membranes, because oxidized acyl chains are turned into the aquatic environment. The sharp decrease in the level of ROS-positive host cells at the end of the experiment may be resulted from an intensive utilization of ROS for the oxPE and oxPS synthesis (Farmer and Mueller, 2013; O'Donnell et al., 2019) . Most likely, the recovery of the coral becomes impossible, when damaged cells were over accumulated.

The lipidomic results of the present study agreed with our recent data on Sinularia sp. bleaching (Sikorskaya et al., 2020) and confirmed the rising in biosynthesis of long-term storage lipids such as waxes (WX) up to 48 h of heat exposure. At the same time, the content of total structural lipids declined but the proportions between the major structural phospholipid classes (PC/PE/PS/CAEP/LPE) were quite stable. It means that S. heterospiculata can turn on the mechanisms of energy accumulation for future recovery and keep the structure of biological membranes. If the heat stress continues, a considerable amount of storage lipids is utilized, a hydrolytic and oxidase degradation of the storage lipids increases like an avalanche, cell structures are destroyed, and coral colonies die.

Thus, the domination of different mechanisms in each bleaching stage are supposed. Exocytosis is assumed to predominate during the first day (earlier stage) of the soft coral bleaching. Then, within 24-48 h of heat exposure, the remaining degraded zooxanthellae were destroyed by the coral host innate immune system, which leads to their intracellular digestion. Necrosis and degradation of the coral cells and tissues were observed at the end of the experiment. The relationships between lipidome and each process accompanying coral bleaching were found, but requires further research. We believe that lipidomic parameters may become reliable indicators of physiological processes occurring in the coral symbiotic organism.

The conditions of our experiment may occur in nature in shallow lagoons, where the water temperature can reach 35 • C and remain constant for several hours. We assume that the Sinularia soft corals are able to quickly repair damages after one day of a heat stress, but longer heat exposure is critical to coral health and requires a long-term recovery period (Sikorskaya et al., 2020) .

(C, D) Epidermis; asterisks indicate epidermal degrading cells. (E) Apical part of epidermal cells (F) Degrading epidermal cells. (G) Structures with disintegrated myofibrils. (H) Myelin-like bodies. (I) Basal part of the epidermis. FIGREF1.text: Microscopic organization of host cells in the tentacle gastrodermis of S. heterospiculata, cultivated at normal condition (27 • С) and after heat stress (33 • С). Transmission electron micrographs of S. heterospiculata tentacle cross sections. (A) General view of a gastrodermis; asterisks indicate zooxanthellae. (B) Dividing zooxanthellae. (C, D) General view of a gastrodermis after heat stress; asterisks indicate zooxanthellae. (E) Host cell with symbiosome. (F) Host cell with symbiophagosome. (G) Symbiosome membrane structure. (H) Golgi apparatus. (I, J) Phagosome and symbiophagosome in host cells, respectively. (K) Necrotic zooxanthellae and residual bodies in the host cell cytoplasm. (L) Thylakoid membranes in the residual body.
